description: Borrowed from Middle French instance, from Latin īnstantia (“a being near, presence, also perseverance, earnestness, importunity, urgency”), from īnstāns (“urgent”); see instant.

entries.meaning: (obsolete) Urgency of manner or words; an urgent request; insistence. [14th–19th c.]
(obsolete) A token; a sign; a symptom or indication.
(obsolete) A piece of evidence; a proof or sign (of something). [16th–18th c.]
A case offered as an exemplification or a precedent; an illustrative example. [from 16th c.]
One of a series of recurring occasions, cases, essentially the same.
(computing) A specific occurrence of something that is created or instantiated, such as a database, or an object of a class in object-oriented programming. [from 20th c.]

(massively multiplayer online games) A dungeon or other area that is duplicated for each player, or each party of players, that enters it, so that each player or party has a private copy of the area, isolated from other players.
examples: As long as the most difficult instance you've tried is Gnomeregan, you're never going to be credible talking about 'difficult encounters'.

entries.meaning: (massively multiplayer online games) An individual copy of such a dungeon or other area.
examples: The instance is created for the group that enters it.

verbs.description: instance (third-person singular simple present instances, present participle instancing, simple past and past participle instanced)

entries.meaning: (transitive) To mention as a case or example; to refer to; to cite
examples: The poems which I have instanced are concrete and relatively glaring examples of the intangible difference which the change of language made in Rilke's visions .

entries.meaning: (intransitive) To cite an example as proof; to exemplify.
